DataElement.preferredDefinition: The Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) technique used to administer the tumor identification assessment.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Tumor Identifier Domain Tumor Identifier Method
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A domain that represents the data that uniquely identifies tumors._The technique used to administer the tumor identification assessment.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A domain that represents the data that uniquely identifies tumors.

Concepts.definition: A domain that represents the data that uniquely identifies tumors.

Property.preferredDefinition: The technique used to administer the tumor identification assessment.

Concepts.definition: The technique used to administer the tumor identification assessment.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: An organizational header for concepts representing mostly abstract entities.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Standard parameters to be used when documenting response of solid tumors to treatment; a set of published rules that define when cancer patients improve ("respond"), stay the same ("stable"), or worsen ("progression") during treatments. (from www.recist.com)_A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Concepts.definition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.
A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

Concepts.definition: The study of the structure of the cells and their arrangement to constitute tissues and, finally, the association among these to form organs.  In pathology, the microscopic process of identifying normal and abnormal morphologic characteristics in tissues, by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Laparoscopic examination of the abdominal cavity and its contents.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure during which a laparoscope is inserted into the abdomen to view the abdominopelvic contents for diagnostic and/or therapeutic purposes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A technique in which high-frequency sound waves are bounced off internal organs and the echo pattern is converted into a 2 dimensional picture of the structures beneath the transducer.

Concepts.definition: The use of high-frequency sound waves to generate images of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method of examining body organs by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Concepts.definition: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An x-ray examination of the chest.

Concepts.definition: An x-ray examination of the chest.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure that uses an endoscope to examine the inside of the body. An endoscope is a thin, tube-like instrument with a light and a lens for viewing. It may also have a tool to remove tissue to be checked under a microscope for signs of disease.

Concepts.definition: A diagnostic or therapeutic procedure in which an endoscope is inserted in a tubular organ to examine the structural architecture and/or remove abnormal tissues.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The light microscopic study of normal and abnormal cells in fine needle aspirates (FNAs), body cavity fluids, and smears.

Concepts.definition: The light microscopic study of normal and abnormal cells in fine needle aspirates (FNAs), body cavity fluids, and smears.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A caliper for clinical use is a compass-like device intended for use in measuring the thickness or diameter of a part of the body or the distance between two body surfaces, such as for measuring an excised skeletal specimen to determine the proper replacement size of a prosthesis.

Concepts.definition: A caliper for clinical use is a compass-like device intended for use in measuring the thickness or diameter of a part of the body or the distance between two body surfaces, such as for measuring an excised skeletal specimen to determine the proper replacement size of a prosthesis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The appearance of objects (or light sources) described in terms of a person's perception of their hue and lightness (or brightness) and saturation.: The process by which an image is acquired by recording light emissions on radiation-sensitive paper.: Add as part of something else; put in as part of a set, group, or category.: A device used for measuring, or for drawing straight lines, consisting of an elongated piece of rigid or semi-rigid material marked with units of measurement.

Concepts.definition: The appearance of objects (or light sources) described in terms of a person's perception of their hue and lightness (or brightness) and saturation.
The process by which an image is acquired by recording light emissions on radiation-sensitive paper.
Add as part of something else; put in as part of a set, group, or category.
A device used for measuring, or for drawing straight lines, consisting of an elongated piece of rigid or semi-rigid material marked with units of measurement.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

Concepts.definition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A variation in cellular or biochemical components or processes, structures, or functions that is objectively measurable in a biological system and that characterizes normal biologic processes, pathogenic processes, an organism's state of health or disease, likelihood of developing a disease, prognosis, or response to a particular therapeutic intervention. Biomarkers include but not limited to such phenotypic parameters as specific enzyme or hormone concentration, specific gene phenotype, presence or absence of biological substances.

Concepts.definition: A characteristic that can be objectively measured and serves as an indicator for normal biologic processes, pathogenic processes, state of health or disease, the risk for disease development and/or prognosis, or responsiveness to a particular therapeutic intervention.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.: Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.

Concepts.definition: A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.
Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A nuclear imaging method used to evaluate pathological bone metabolism.

Concepts.definition: A nuclear imaging method used to evaluate pathological bone metabolism.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the response criteria (includes RECIST and others) and associated documentation of disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors Method Type

(from www.recist.com):A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.:Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

Concepts.longName: Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors
Concepts.definition: Standard parameters to be used when documenting response of solid tumors to treatment; a set of published rules that define when cancer patients improve ("respond"), stay the same ("stable"), or worsen ("progression") during treatments. (from www.recist.com)
A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueDomain.origin: RECIST:Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors
ValueDomain.changeDescription: 11/14/18 jk "Bone scan" added per RECIST v1.1 guideline, section 3.1.3 - Bone lesions.  10/23/18 jk chg reg status to Standard for RECIST defined PV list; do not add PVs without checking latest version of guideline.   8/30/17 tt VD versioned for change to PVs, transferred context, added CSI and reg status per Round 5 finalization task. 6/19/16 released. jk 5/7/15 added PET/CT as value as referenced in Appendix II of guideline and Round 5 comments. jc  3/20/15 Added max length; Changed "clinical lesion" to "clinical exam", added PE as alt name; Changed "marker" to "Tumor marker". jc  7/9/14 added caliper per section 3.2.2.-clinical lesion. jc 8/20/13 created for RECIST CRF module; values from RECISTv1.1 Guideline, section 3.2.2.  jc
